awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Investigating Thermal Structure, Dynamics, and Dehydration in the Tropical Tropopause Layer with Fiber Optic Temperature Profiling from Strateole-2 Balloons
awd_abstract_narration:
The tropical tropopause layer (TTL) is transition zone between the troposphere (the domain of clouds, precipitation, and weather systems) and the stratosphere (the cold and dry region above it which contains the ozone layer).  The TTL extends from about 14 to 18.5km over the tropics and is above the tops of all but the tallest convective clouds.  It often contains thin cirrus clouds which, though difficult to see, play an outsized role in trapping outgoing radiation and thus warming the troposphere.  It is sometimes called the "gateway to the stratosphere" because most of the water vapor in the stratosphere, and many other stratospheric constituents, enter the stratosphere by moving upward through the TTL.  The stratosphere is extremely dry compared to the troposphere, but stratospheric water vapor is of interest because it has an important greenhouse effect and can lead to the formation of polar stratospheric clouds which play a role in ozone hole formation.

Work under this project seeks to improve understanding of the TTL by developing and deploying a temperature profiler as part of a long-duration ballooning campaign.  The profiler, with the acronym FLOATS (Fiber-optic Laser Operated Atmospheric Temperature Sensor), measures temperature along a fiber optic cable 2km long which is suspended below a balloon gondola.  FLOATS works by injecting laser light into a fiber optic cable and sensing Raman backscattered light. It can measure temperature with 0.3K precision and a vertical resolution of 3m, generating a profile every two to five minutes.  A proof-of-concept prototype was developed under an EAGER award, AGS-1419932.  

FLOATS is deployed as part of the Strateole-2 field campaign organized by the Centre National d'Etudes Spatiales (CNES), the French Space Agency, and the Laboratoire de Meteorologie Dynamic (LMD) of the University of Paris-Saclay.  Strateole-2 is a five-year campaign, with a small validation deployment in 2018 and full science deployments in 2020-2021 and 2022-2023.  Balloons are launched  from the Seychelles (about 5S in the Indian Ocean), with the expectation that each balloon will circle the earth for up to 90 days and observe the TTL between 20S and 15N. This award supports US participation in the validation campaign and the first full science deployment, along with post-campaign analysis.  It is one of three awards made to US PIs for participation in Strateole-2, the full set being AGS-1643022, AGS-1642277/1642246, and AGS-1642650/1653644.

The FLOATS measurements are used to address three scientific objectives, all of which use temperature variations along the fiber optic cable to examine the behavior of gravity waves (wave motions in the air in which buoyancy provides the restoring force).  The first is the depression of the cold point tropopause (CPT) temperature by vertically propagating gravity waves, which is a key factor in determining how much water vapor enters the stratosphere through the TTL.  If condensation or sublimation occurs when relative humidity reaches 100%, then the amount of water vapor entering the stratosphere should not exceed the amount corresponding to 100% relative humidity at the CPT temperature. Earlier work by one of the PIs and others suggests that wave-induced CPT temperature depression could be significant, and an increase in wave activity could be responsible for a substantial portion of the decrease in CPT temperature and stratospheric water vapor believed to have occurred in the first decade of the 21st century.   The second science objective is to understand the role of gravity waves in producing cirrus clouds in the TTL.  The problem is complementary to stratospheric dehydration produced by temperature depression, as water vapor prevented from entering the stratosphere by colder temperatures instead freezes out to form cirrus ice particles.

The third objective is to measure the vertical momentum flux associated with the waves.  These waves are critical for the stratospheric quasi-biennial oscillation (QBO), which can influence the skill of long-range weather forecasts.  Momentum flux would be estimated by combining FLOATS measurements (which give wave amplitude, vertical wavelength, and phase speed) with additional measurement taken on the balloon gondola including wave-induced directional displacement inferred from GPS positioning.

The work has scientific broader impacts due to the value of the observations for addressing a variety of questions regarding TTL processes and the stratospheric QBO.  In particular, wave momentum flux data is of value for developing gravity wave parameterizations for use in improving numerical models used for weather forecasting.  FLOATS observations will be made available to the research community from servers at the Laboratory for Atmospheric and Space Physics at the University of Colorado Boulder, so that they can be freely examined by the research community.  In addition, the project constitutes a demonstration of a novel technology for meteorological observations which could have a wide array of scientific applications. Beyond these considerations, the project supports a postdoctoral research associate, thereby developing the future scientific workforce in this research area.

por.por_cntn:
This project involved the development of a one-mile-long fiber optic distributed temperature sensor, the Fiberoptic Laser Operated Atmospheric Temperature Sensor (FLOATS). Three of these were then deployed from long duration super pressure balloons which circled the globe at the equator.  The goal of this measurement was to characterize the temperature structure of the Tropical Tropopause Layer – the primary gateway for air entering the stratosphere.   The FLOATS project was an ambitious high-risk, high-reward project, that yielded valuable data about waves in the Tropical Tropopause, but also the limits of distributed temperature sensing at some of the coldest temperatures occurring on earth (colder than -110oF).   The FLOATS instrument design is shown in Figure 1 – consisting of one mile of Kevlar reinforced fiber optic, a reel system to deploy this fiber in flight, a laser system to measure the temperature of the fiber every 6 feet and an end of fiber unit to record the position of the bottom end of the fiber.  

 

Four Floats instruments were deployed on balloons, one on a short duration test flight from Laramie Wyoming (Figure 2), which proved the viability of this measurement technique to gather ultra-high resolution vertical temperature measurements of the lower stratosphere while drifting on a balloon.   The high-speed and high-resolution measurements form a temperature curtain as the balloon drifts through the atmosphere.   Three more instruments were deployed from the Seychelles in the Indian Ocean aboard long duration balloons operated by the French Space Agency.   One of these instruments recorded a short, one-day long measurement set before the balloon experienced a premature failure, a second instrument experienced a mechanical issue where the fiber became entangled on another instrument, but the third instrument collected more than 1300 temperature profiles across the tropopause while drifting hundreds of kilometers (figure 3).  These measurements form a temperature curtain through the Tropical Tropopause Layer, however, due to the extremely cold temperatures encountered, the temperature dependent signal, known as Raman Scattering, was extremely low, near the detection level of the instrument, making the processing of the data and extraction of the temperature signal very difficult.

 

A fourth FLOATS instrument was planned to be flown on a long duration flight from the Seychelles, however this instrument suffered a catastrophic failure of the laser system shortly before launch.  As the balloon flight would proceed with or without the FLOATS instrument, the team of field scientist at the launch site quickly re-engineered the parts of FLOATS that were still operational – the reel system to deploy several hundred meters of fiber optic cable and the end of cable unit that has both a GPS for position and a reference grade temperature sensor – to form a new instrument the Reeldown Atmospheric Temperature Sensor or RATS that simultaneously measures temperature at two different altitudes with drifting at the top of the Tropical Tropopause Layer.    The improvised RATS instrument was successfully flown as the final mission of this project recording multiple weeks of differential temperature profiles.

 

The data from the FLOATS and RATS instruments we analyzed to characterize the wavelength and period of waves in the Tropical Tropopause Layer, which are the energetic drivers of several large-scale circulations in the atmosphere, including the Quasi Biennial Oscillation (QBO) – which is characterized by a reversal in stratospheric winds approximately (but not exactly) every two years.  The analysis method identifies covarying temperature signals in the two continuous time series at the two altitudes, then uses the observed fractional phase shift Df between the two signals to infer the vertical wavelength Lz using a simple equation Lz = Dz / Df. The length Dz and measurement uncertainties limit the possible range of Lz observable with the RATS measurements to the range Lz = 400m to 6km. This is a range that we knew from earlier work would straddle the range of resolvable waves in the best global weather forecasts available. Indeed, a comparison of waves seen in RATS data to those weather data revealed that the weather data and RATS observation agree when the wave vertical wavelength Lz = 5 km, but RATS also observed a short Lz = 1.5 km that was missing in the weather data. This maiden flight of RATS proved that the concept works, and plans are underway to fly RATS instruments on five new long duration balloons in 2025. If these 2025 measurements are successful, we stand to learn a great deal about this new class of extremely-thin-but-broad gravity wave and their collective effects on weather forecasting and near- term climate prediction.
